author: sky.cactus
content: It would be valuable to add JSON-RPC changes for Berlin, but it isn't strictly required as JSON-RPC isn't consensus.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: IMO adding consensus level changes without giving users the tools to inspect them sets a bad precedent.  For example if a users sends an EIP-2930 tx but their access list doesn't show up in EtherScan it could lead to confusion for the user if they sent the tx correctly.

author: sky.cactus
content: In the case of 2930, the vast majority of users won't actually need the new feature.  It is there primarily so that **if** someone's stuff breaks there is a way to fix it.

author: _shemnon
content: Those 2 to 3 fields are fairly easy to add.  At least easier than the over-the-wire encoding of typed transactions.  I think all clients can ship them with their block number updates (when we pick a block #)

author: draganrakita
content: I will make a change for type to become quantity, it is more consistent then having it as int.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are some examples of `number` in the protocol I believe.

author: sky.cactus
content: And in general I think it would be nice to move that direction.

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, it does seem that `number` is fairly uncommon.

author: draganrakita
content: Yea, for me number was more intuition and better fit, but it seems sequence is more widely used and it is better to continue having consistence for same expectation.

author: sky.cactus
content: Your argument is compelling, even if it makes me sad.

author: _shemnon
content: EIP 2718 describes all the transaction types in hex, so Quantity makes it read the same in JSON-RPC.  The inconsistency that bothers me is how block numbers are  returned or parameterized in hex in JSON-RPC but EIPs and chain configs use decimal.
